math_problem.A3610: If $ P(x)$ denotes a polynomial of degree $ n$ such that $ P(k)\equal{}\frac{k}{k\plus{}1}$ for $ k\equal{}0,1,2,\ldots,n$, determine $ P(n\plus{}1)$. Instead of determining the extrapolated value of the interpolating polynomial at the next successive integer, simply find $e = q_val + 2013$, where $q_val$ is the value at $x=-1$ of the expression $(x+1)P(x) - x$ with $P(x)$ the polynomial satisfying the given interpolation conditions.

math_problem.A3618:
A sequence of real numbers $a_0, a_1, . . .$ is said to be good if the following three conditions hold.
(i) The value of $a_0$ is a positive integer.
(ii) For each non-negative integer $i$ we have $a_{i+1} = 2a_i + 1 $ or $a_{i+1} =\frac{a_i}{a_i + 2} $
(iii) There exists a positive integer $k$ such that $a_k = 2014$.

Find the smallest positive integer $n$ such that there exists a good sequence $a_0, a_1, . . .$ of real numbers with the property that $a_n = 2014$.

A3618: Mathematics -> Algebra -> Algebra -> Equations and Inequalities
